stories.title: The Thief of Khar-Zul
stories.text: Vraxen the Knife had robbed a hundred merchant princes, but never a god. The idol of Khar-Zul squatted in the temple's inner dark, its nine emerald eyes worth more than most kingdoms. He pried the first gem free. The stone was warmâobscenely so. By the third, the shadows were moving. By the sixth, they had teeth. Vraxen sprinted for the portico, the remaining three eyes blazing at his back like green suns. He burst into moonlight, gems clutched to his chest. Behind him the temple screamed in a voice of grinding granite. He ran until his lungs tore. At dawn, camped in a dry riverbed, he counted his prize: six emeralds. He did not count the new shadow that crouched beside him, patient as carved stone, wearing the shape of his own face.

stories.title: Blood-Price of the Caravan
stories.text: The merchant Aldric paid Soraya the sell-sword in gold to escort his spice caravan across the Ashen Wastes. He paid the bandits in silver to let it pass. He paid the toll-lord in promises. When the caravan crested the final ridge above Pelimor, Soraya discovered he'd also paid a blood-sorcerer in something far more precious. The drivers' shadows were wrongâtoo thick, too still. One by one they turned, eyes like tarnished coins. Soraya killed nine men that night, weeping, because she'd eaten beside them for three weeks. She killed the sorcerer last, slowly. She kept none of Aldric's gold. But she took his shadow, rolled it tight as a scroll, and sold it in the night markets of Pelimor to a buyer who never gave his name. She told herself it was justice. Some nights she believed it.

stories.title: The Lamp of Suroth
stories.text: Below the Sunken Ziggurat of Yeng, in a chamber where the air tasted of centuries, Malachite Doss found the lamp. It was iron, ugly, and full of something that was not oil. The inscription above the niche read: He who lights this buys one truth at the cost of one lie he has lived by. Doss was a scholar. He had lived by many lies. He struck flint. The flame burned black. The truth that came was smallâhis dead wife had not loved him, only his library. He'd known this for thirty years without knowing it. The lie that the flame consumed was larger: the belief that knowledge was its own reward. He stood in the dark long after the lamp guttered out. Then he climbed toward the surface, lighter and heavier at once, already wondering what lay beneath the next sealed door.

stories.title: Siege of the Bone Citadel
stories.text: Kael Bloodhorn brought eight hundred Veth warriors to the walls of the Bone Citadel and lost six hundred of them before he understood the fortress was alive. The towers breathed. The gates digested. He lost another hundred learning where the heart wasâa pulsing white chamber deep beneath the foundation, fed by roots that spread under the whole steppe. He sent his last hundred in through the drainage tunnels with torches. They did not come back. But the Citadel screamed. It screamed for three days. On the fourth morning it was still, and Kael walked its corridors alone. He found his warriors in the wallsâabsorbed, preserved, their faces visible beneath the bone-white surface like insects in amber. They were breathing. He spent the rest of his life trying to get them out. He failed. But he never stopped.

stories.title: The Curse of Yarithax's Gold
stories.text: Every coin from Yarithax's hoard bore the Lich-King's profile and a small inscription on the reverse: This debt is not yet settled. Tessaly Dorn had spent twelve of them before she read the fine print. By then the collectors had found her. They were not impressiveâtwo thin men in grey, carrying ledgers. But they could walk through walls, and they never slept, and the debt they quoted in their dry voices compounded daily at a rate that would consume kingdoms. She offered them her soul. They consulted their ledgers. They shook their heads. A soul, they explained, was worth considerably less than twelve gold marks of Yarithax. She offered them ten years of her life. They noted it down, subtracted, and told her she still owed nine months, fourteen days, and several hours. She paid in service. Eleven months chasing debts for the dead. She collected punctually. She understood the job.

stories.title: The Oath-Breaker's Due
stories.text: Pieter Vane broke his oath to the dead king on a Tuesday, for twenty gold pieces and a horse. He spent the gold in a month. The horse went lame. The dead king came for him on a Wednesday. He was patient about itâdeath gives perspective on time. He found Pieter in a dockside tavern, three provinces away, and sat down across from him with the quiet ease of a man with nowhere else to be. He did not threaten. He merely asked if Pieter remembered the exact words of the oath. Pieter recited them, slowly, because he had not forgottenâhad never for one moment forgotten. The dead king nodded. Then you know what comes next. Pieter did. He'd known since Tuesday. He finished his drink. He paid his tab. He followed the dead king out into the cold street, and no one ever saw Pieter Vane again, though travelers sometimes reported a new tomb, unmarked, on the north road.

stories.title: The Sorcerer's Debt
stories.text: Conjuress Mel owed the demon Varek three favors for three spells cast in desperation during the Siege of Amrath. She'd counted on Varek forgetting. Demons, she'd reasoned, were busy. The first favor was small: deliver a letter to a dead man. She managed it. The second was moderate: steal a year from a sleeping child. She refused, and spent a month being reminded why refusal was inadvisable. She stole the year. The third favor Varek named on her wedding morning. He stood in the church door, elegant as plague, and named his price: the marriage itself. Happiness, he explained, was more valuable than years or letters. It was his finest collection. She drew the circle fastâshe'd had months to prepare itâand took the fourth option no mortal ever considered: she offered Varek herself, in contract, as a fellow collector. He paused. He was genuinely surprised. He agreed. It was a better arrangement for them both.

stories.title: The Barbarian's Mercy
stories.text: Urgha the Unmoved killed four men before breakfast on the day she showed mercy, which tells you something about her mornings. The fifth man was the emperor's tax collector, small and damp and weeping, and he was weeping because his daughter was ill and he'd spent the collection on physicians and didn't know what to tell the emperor. Urgha had been hired by the emperor to retrieve the funds or the collector's ears. She stood in the muddy courtyard for a long time. She was not known for standing. She went inside and looked at the daughter, who was six and burning with fever and who looked, in the particular way of feverish children, like everyone's child. Urgha left the courtyard with neither money nor ears. She sent her own physicianâshe had one, mercenaries often didâand paid for it herself. She remained unmoved. She was very, very angry about the mercy for years afterward.

stories.title: The Last Thief of Crimson Gate
stories.text: The demon offered Cassia Vorn the usual things first: wealth, power, the life of her enemy. She declined each in turn with the brisk efficiency of someone who'd read the relevant literature. The demon, unused to educated clients, grew uncertain. What do you want? it finally asked, dropping the sales pitch. She told it: the name of the man who'd burned Crimson Gate, her city, with three thousand people still inside. The demon went still. Names, it said, carefully, were expensive. Not power or gold, but informationâinformation was the coin of a different, older economy. She said she understood. She offered the thing the demon actually wanted: not her soul, which was common, but her certainty. She was the most certain person the demon had ever met, and certainty in a mortal was intoxicating to beings made of doubt. She left with the name. She became notably less certain afterward, but she used the name, and that was enough.

stories.title: The Plague-Bringer's Crown
stories.text: King Aldous III won the war by importing the Plague-Bringer's Crown from the sealed vault beneath Ostern and setting it on his head for thirty seconds. Thirty seconds was, the scholars assured him, survivable. They were nearly right. He won. The enemy kingdom surrendered before the siege engines were deployed, because an army that watches its opponent crown himself with a relic that killed four previous wearers understands it faces a man with nothing left to lose. Aldous reigned for eleven more years. He was not a good kingâhe was erratic, sleepless, prone to speaking to people who were not in the roomâbut he was a king no one ever tried to depose. When he died, finally, of ordinary causes, the physicians found his shadow had been on backwards for years, which explained certain things. The Crown was returned to Ostern. They built a deeper vault.

stories.title: The Crimson Covenant of Vex-Karthul
stories.text:
Malachar the Betrayer came to the obsidian temple seeking redemption, but the daemon-priests offered only damnation. They showed him visions: empires crumbling to dust, the sun bleeding crimson across blackened skies. The price? His soul, bound in parchment written in blood.

He signed.

For three decades, Malachar conquered kingdoms, his sword thirsty and inexhaustible. But the daemon's hunger grew insatiable. On the night they came to collect their due, Malachar stood alone in his throne room, surrounded by the corpses of his own generals. He laughedâa terrible, broken soundâand drove his blade through his own heart. Better to deny them their prize than be enslaved.

The contract burned to ash. The daemons shrieked across the void.

In his final moment, Malachar understood: defiance was its own salvation.

stories.title: Shara of the Scorched Wastes
stories.text:
The witch-queen Thysara had ruled the Scorched Wastes for a thousand years, sustained by stolen youth and blood-sorcery. Her enemies crumbled to dust. Her beauty was eternal.

Shara was just a slave girl when she arrived at the palace. Thysara marked her immediatelyâfresh blood for the midnight rituals.

But Shara had walked through deserts wider than death itself. In the ritual chamber, bound to the blood-stone, she whispered words the old nomads had taught her. Ancient words. Cantrips of sand and sun.

Thysara's eternal youth reversed in heartbeats. Her skin withered like autumn leaves. She aged a thousand years in a single scream.

Shara walked from that palace into the morning sun, leaving behind only a mummified husk upon a forgotten throne. The wastes belonged to her now.

stories.title: The Hunger of Grell Ironhand
stories.text:
Grell Ironhand was the greatest sellsword in the Shattered Provincesâuntil the magic plague took his sword arm. Metal was grafted where flesh had been, cold and beautiful and useless.

The apothecary in Blackmark promised restoration for a price: venture into the Singing Catacombs and retrieve the Heartstone of Vulgrim the Damned.

Grell descended into darkness. The catacombs whispered in languages that predated humanity. Corpses hung from chains, singing mournfully. He found Vulgrim's corpse at the lowest depthsâa thing of withered malice clutching a stone that pulsed with terrible life.

He took it.

The apothecary's fingers were trembling when Grell returned. "This will restore you," she whispered, "but it hungers. It will demand tribute. Blood. Always blood."

Grell looked at his iron hand. For a moment, he considered simply walking away. Instead, he crushed the Heartstone beneath his heel. Some prices were too high to ever pay.

stories.title: Zareth Among the Stellar Stones
stories.text:
The astronomer-prince Zareth had spent his life studying the stars, charting the movements of celestial spheres. But the stars were dying. He could feel itâa cosmic senescence creeping across the heavens.

The Elder Stones stood in the Wastes of Ashemark, ancient beyond reckoning. Those who touched them could commune with the dying constellations themselves.

Zareth placed his palms against the weathered stone. Knowledge flooded his mind: the universe was cyclical, stars burned out only to reignite. This death was necessary. Resistance was futile.

But Zareth was no ordinary mortal. He pulled back and laughedâa sound like breaking glass. He would build towers. Observatories. He would teach mankind to read the stars so that when the new heavens bloomed, they would recognize beauty in the eternal cycle.

He turned his back on the stones and walked toward distant cities, his purpose crystalline.

stories.title: The Debt of Kessa the Thief
stories.text:
Kessa stole the Eye of Aethon from the Temple of the Sleeping God, and immediately the priests' curse fell upon her. Her shadow began hunting herâa living darkness that moved with predatory intent.

She ran through the Quarantine Streets, through sewers and crypts, but the shadow was inexorable. It grew stronger, fed by her fear.

In the Tomb of Dead Merchants, Kessa made her stand. She turned to face the shadow directly and did something desperate: she embraced it. Pulled it into herself.

For a moment, she was two creatures at onceâlight and darkness, thief and pursuer. Then they merged. The curse broke.

Kessa emerged different. Her left half moved in darkness, her right in light. Perfect balance. She looked at the Eye of Aethon in her hand and smiled. The Sleeping God had given her more than she'd stolen: it had given her wholeness.

She walked toward the rising sun, her shadow no longer her enemy.

stories.title: Dravok's Last Gamble
stories.text:
The sorcerer-king Dravok had conquered three empires through will and black magic, but his power was waning. The runes of immortality were fading. Death finally claimed him at the edges of his perception.

He sought the Crimson Sanctuary, where the Gambler's Daemon dweltâa being of pure chaos that granted one final wish to the dying. The price: stake everything. Win, and gain eternal life. Lose, and be erased utterly from existence and memory.

Dravok entered the Sanctuary and sat across from the Daemon. They played a game with bones carved from reality itself.

Dravok lost.

But as he felt himself dissolving, he laughed. The Daemon paused, confused. "I won," Dravok whispered. "I've finally lost something that matters." His empire crumbled to dust. Statues toppled. Records burned. He ceased to exist.

And in ceasing to exist, the tyrant finally became free.

stories.title: The Lamia's Pearl
stories.text:
The pearl diver Torven sought the Lamia's Pearl in the Sunken Caverns, a treasure said to grant control over water itself. The merfolk had warned him: the Lamia guarded it jealously, and she was ancient beyond measure.

He found her coiled in darknessâa creature of incomparable beauty and terrible hunger. Her eyes held centuries of loneliness.

"Why do you seek the pearl?" she asked.

"My village drowns slowly," Torven said. "The seas recede. We starve."

The Lamia was silent for a long time. Then she began to weep. Her tears filled the cavern, becoming a luminescent substance. "Take them," she said. "My tears have more power than any pearl. I have wept alone in darkness for so long that no one remembers my name."

Torven took the tears and helped the Lamia into the light. His village thrived. And the Lamia, no longer alone, finally found peace.

stories.title: Vex the Curse-Bearer
stories.text:
Vex was born with a curse: every kindness she performed rebounded with terrible vengeance. She saved a child from bandits; his parents were slaughtered by forces unseen. She shared food with the starving; plague followed in her wake.

So she became a killer insteadâa mercenary who made her living through violence. At least then the curse served a purpose.

One night, a sorcerer offered her a deal: he would lift the curse if she killed his enemy. She agreed and performed the murder with her usual brutal efficiency.

But the curse remained.

The sorcerer laughed. "The curse was never a punishment," he said. "It was a gift. You were meant to understand that intention and consequence are never simple. Your darkness saved countless lives."

Vex drove her blade through him, understanding at last. She walked away from mercenary work entirely, seeking only solitude. In isolation, her curse harmed no one. In isolation, she was finally at peace.

stories.title: Morgath's Resurrection
stories.text:
The necromancer Morgath had been dead for a hundred years when his apprentices exhumed his bones and began the resurrection rite. They needed himâa plague of un-death was consuming the Northlands.

Morgath arose, confused and terrible. His power had grown in death, his understanding of mortality deepened. He saw what his former apprentices had become: tyrants, using his dark arts to enslave the living.

He destroyed them all.

Then he turned his vast power toward the un-death plague. He saw the truth: it was a natural cycle, the world cleansing itself. Fighting it only prolonged suffering.

Morgath performed one final ritualâhe bound his own power into the earth, sealing away the knowledge of necromancy. His apprentices' grimoires crumbled to dust. Then he walked into the Eternal Dark willingly.

This time, death held him. And in that darkness, the great sorcerer found something he'd never known: forgiveness.

stories.title: The Stone Woman of Kalthara
stories.text:
In the ruins of Kalthara stood a statueâa woman carved from black stone, her face twisted in eternal despair. The local tribes said she had refused a sorcerer's love and been cursed to stone.

The barbarian Kael came seeking her because legend promised that breaking her curse would grant unimaginable power.

He struck the statue with his enchanted blade. Cracks spiderwebbed across the stone. As they widened, knowledge poured outâcenturies of memories, the stolen lives of a thousand women transformed to adorning the ruins.

But Kael understood now. This was not a curse to breakâit was a prison holding back something ancient and ravenous. Each statue was a seal.

He stepped back and cast the blade away. Instead, he spent his life tending the ruins, maintaining the stones, keeping the seals intact. When he finally died, a new guardian rose to take his place.

Some powers were never meant to be freed. Some sacrifices were made to save the world itself.
